instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1708: What is A1708? A1708 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2017, 2016 with EMC 3164, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00840, 820-00875..
definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.CHGR_ACOK: What is CHGR_ACOK? This is identical to SMC_BC_ACOK. This will come out of the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging chip when CHGR_ACIN & CHGR_DCIN are present, and is necessary for the onewire circuit to begin working. On most Macbooks, CHGR_ACOK needs to be present in order for PP3V42_G3H to flow to the onewire circuit so that the circuitry that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC will turn on.  .
definitions.PM_EN_P3V3_G3H: What is PM_EN_P3V3_G3H? PM_EN_P3V3_G3H is a signal that enables the PP3V3_G3H rail to turn on. This comes out of ISL9239 or ISL9240 chip; when missing, often is missing because of a bad ISL9239 or ISL9240 chip. .
definitions.R7020: What is R7020? Current sense shunt resistor for the charger, the resistors between this and the ISL6259 should be proper rating or else machine will turn off the charger. Measuring pins 27/28 on ISL6259 should give you 20.02 ohms. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 20V 0A no <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
This board was liquid damage with 5V 0A. Corrosion at <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> and nearby, also the PI3USB32 chip (the one we don't see on schematic &brdvw) was corroded.
Reflowed both of them and replaced all resistors around both CD32s.

Now I get 20v 0A and <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 0V with no short (diode mode 0,410)
Replaced <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> and <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR>/40 and it's the same (20V 0A).

At <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>
<SIGNAL>AUX_DET</SIGNAL> 5v
<RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR>/21/61/62 are ok
<SIGNAL>TBA_HPWR_EN_L</SIGNAL> 3.4V
<SIGNAL>PM_EN_P3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> 5V
<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_R_L</SIGNAL> / <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_R</SIGNAL> 3.4V
<SIGNAL>SMC_CHGR_INT_L</SIGNAL> 3.4V
<SIGNAL>CHGR_ACOK</SIGNAL> 3,3V
<SIGNAL>SMC_RST_IN</SIGNAL> 0V
<SIGNAL>PD_SMC_CBC_ON</SIGNAL> 0V

I don't know if even I get 20V I still need to check again near CD32 or even replace them, or something related with SMC?
Don't know what to check anymore at this point.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 20V 0A no <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
<CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips should be good now, if switch to 20V.
Check other <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> voltages; VDDA/P, <SIGNAL>VR1_3P3</SIGNAL>, A/BMON.
Compare diode mode readings on secondary power supplies with good board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 20V 0A no <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Oh forgot to post other <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> voltages:
<RESISTOR>R7075</RESISTOR> is 5ohms and VDDA/VDDP is 5V
<SIGNAL>VR1_3P3</SIGNAL> is 3.3V 
A/BMON are both 0V / 0V (char only) with working board I get 0,050V / 0V (charger only)
<SIGNAL>TBA_COMP</SIGNAL> is 1.1V noticed it was 1,6 and 1,5V on working board

I compared diode mode reading with a working board and I found that
L7900 and L8060 are respectively 0.041 and 0.048 on the patient board as opposed to  0.245 and 0.206 on the working board...

Can I remove the coils, check from where the short is comming and eventually disconnect the feedbacks and see what happen when I plug power?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 20V 0A no <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Not really short, but very low values comparing with good board.
Is sufficient to lift the coils one side; no need to use hot air.
Then check where the low values come from.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 20V 0A no <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
I lifted the coils on one side and found the low values coming from <SIGNAL>PP1V_S5G</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PPVCCPCH_S5G</SIGNAL>...:(
Removed also the feedback resistor going back to the  <CHIP>U7800</CHIP>, but the low diode mode values are still present.
I started to isolate components on the <SIGNAL>PPVCCPCH_S5G</SIGNAL> path (only few caps on this rail) and I can confirm the low diode mode value is coming from <CHIP>U0500</CHIP>. Maybe some crap under the cpu but I think it's a hopeless extremely sensistive fragile board...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 20V 0A no <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Nothing to lose trying to burn eventually crap.
Heat CPU until 180-200 degrees for 15-20s.
Use quality flux, not chinese honey...
